topics.title: Nouns, Articles & Cases (Basics)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Noun Genders (der / die / das), Definite Articles (der / die / das), Indefinite Articles (ein / eine), Compound Nouns, Basic Noun Formation, Diminutives (-chen and -lein), Plural Forms, The Nominative Case, The Accusative Case

sections.title: --- Noun Genders (der / die / das) ---
sections.content: Learn that every German noun has a gender: masculine (der), feminine (die), or neuter (das).

sections.title: What gender means
sections.content: In German, nouns belong to one of three genders; you usually learn the article with the noun. Example: Der Hund ist groß. Example: Die Katze ist klein.

sections.title: Common nouns by gender
sections.content: Some very common nouns: masculine (der Mann, der Tisch), feminine (die Frau, die Schule), neuter (das Kind, das Auto). Example: Der Mann liest ein Buch. Example: Die Frau trinkt Wasser. Example: Das Kind spielt im Haus.

sections.title: How to learn gender fast
sections.content: Say the article every time you learn a noun and use short sentences for practice. Example: Das Buch ist auf dem Tisch. Example: Die Tür ist offen.

sections.title: --- Definite Articles (der / die / das) ---
sections.content: Use definite articles to talk about a specific noun: der, die, das.

sections.title: Meaning of 'the' in German
sections.content: Use a definite article when you mean a specific thing and the listener can identify it. Example: Der Hund ist im Haus. Example: Die Schule ist in der Stadt.

sections.title: Definite articles in the nominative
sections.content: In the nominative (subject) form: der (m.), die (f.), das (n.), die (pl.). Example: Der Tisch ist neu. Example: Das Buch ist hier. Example: Die Freunde sind da.

sections.title: Short everyday sentences
sections.content: A simple pattern is: article + noun + verb + rest. Example: Die Tür ist offen. Example: Der Stuhl ist im Haus.

sections.title: --- Indefinite Articles (ein / eine) ---
sections.content: Use ein/eine/ein to talk about something not specific: a/an.

sections.title: When to use 'a/an'
sections.content: Use an indefinite article when you introduce something new or it is one of many. Example: Ich habe ein Buch. Example: Sie hat eine Katze.

sections.title: Indefinite articles by gender
sections.content: In the nominative: ein (m.), eine (f.), ein (n.); there is no indefinite article for plural. Example: Ein Mann ist hier. Example: Eine Frau kommt. Example: Ein Kind spielt.

sections.title: Simple identification
sections.content: Use ein/eine/ein to say what something is. Example: Das ist ein Auto. Example: Das ist eine Schule.

sections.title: --- Compound Nouns ---
sections.content: Understand how to combine German words to make new nouns.

sections.title: Combining Nouns
sections.content: In German, you can attach nouns directly to each other to form a single, long word. The last word is always the main word. For example: das Haus + die Tür = die Haustür (house door). der Apfel + der Baum = der Apfelbaum (apple tree).

sections.title: Determining the Gender
sections.content: The gender (der, die, or das) of the new compound noun is always decided by the very last noun in the word. For example: die Schule + das Buch = das Schulbuch. das Land + die Straße = die Landstraße.

sections.title: Connecting Letters
sections.content: Sometimes an 's' or an 'n' is added between the nouns to make pronunciation easier. For example: das Kind + das Zimmer = das Kinderzimmer (children's room). der Hund + die Hütte = die Hundehütte (dog house).

sections.title: --- Basic Noun Formation ---
sections.content: Learn simple patterns for turning verbs and adjectives into nouns.

sections.title: Verbs to Nouns (Infinitives)
sections.content: You can turn any verb into a neuter noun by capitalizing its infinitive form. It means 'the act of doing' the verb. For example: Das Lernen ist wichtig. Das Trinken von Wasser ist gut.

sections.title: The -er Suffix for People
sections.content: You can often create a masculine noun for a person doing an action by removing the -en from a verb and adding -er. For example: Der Lehrer hilft dem Kind. Der Schüler liest ein Buch.

sections.title: The -in Suffix for Feminine
sections.content: To make a masculine profession or personal noun feminine, add the suffix '-in'. The plural usually adds '-innen'. For example: Die Lehrerin sieht die Schule. Die Freundin trinkt Milch.

sections.title: --- Diminutives (-chen and -lein) ---
sections.content: Make nouns smaller or cuter using the suffixes -chen and -lein.

sections.title: The Suffix -chen
sections.content: You can make a noun smaller or express affection by adding the suffix '-chen' to the end of it. For example: das Brot becomes das Brötchen (bread roll). Die Katze becomes das Kätzchen (kitten).

sections.title: Always Neuter
sections.content: Whenever you add a diminutive suffix to a noun, its grammatical gender automatically becomes neuter (das), regardless of its original gender. For example: der Hund becomes das Hündchen. Die Frau becomes das Fräulein.

sections.title: Adding Umlauts
sections.content: If the main vowel of the noun is a, o, or u, it usually gets an Umlaut (ä, ö, ü) when the diminutive suffix is added. For example: der Baum (tree) becomes das Bäumchen (little tree). Das Haus becomes das Häuschen.

sections.title: --- Plural Forms ---
sections.content: Form plurals and notice common patterns like -e, -en, -er, and umlaut changes.

sections.title: Plural basics
sections.content: German plurals vary, so learn the plural with the noun. Example: Ein Buch, zwei Bücher. Example: Eine Stadt, zwei Städte.

sections.title: Common plural endings: -e and -en
sections.content: Many nouns add -e or -en, sometimes with an umlaut. Example: Der Tisch, die Tische. Example: Die Frau, die Frauen.

sections.title: Common plural endings: -er and umlaut
sections.content: Some nouns add -er and often change the vowel (umlaut). Example: Das Kind, die Kinder. Example: Der Stuhl, die Stühle.

sections.title: --- The Nominative Case ---
sections.content: Use the nominative case for the subject: the person or thing that does the action.

sections.title: Subject = nominative
sections.content: The subject answers: who/what does the action? The subject is nominative. Example: Der Hund schläft. Example: Die Frau lernt Deutsch.

sections.title: Articles in nominative
sections.content: Nominative articles: der (m.), die (f.), das (n.), die (pl.). Example: Der Mann kommt. Example: Das Kind spielt. Example: Die Freunde lernen Deutsch.

sections.title: With 'sein' (to be)
sections.content: With 'sein', you often say A = B, and both are usually nominative at A1. Example: Der Mann ist ein Freund. Example: Die Stadt ist schön.

sections.title: --- The Accusative Case ---
sections.content: Use the accusative case for the direct object, especially changing masculine articles (der→den, ein→einen).

sections.title: Direct object = accusative
sections.content: The direct object answers: who/what is affected by the action? That noun is accusative. Example: Ich sehe den Hund. Example: Sie kauft einen Apfel.

sections.title: Definite article change (masculine)
sections.content: In accusative, only masculine 'der' changes to 'den' (die and das stay the same). Example: Ich habe den Tisch. Example: Der Mann sieht den Stuhl.

sections.title: Indefinite article change (masculine)
sections.content: In accusative, masculine 'ein' changes to 'einen'. Example: Ich kaufe einen Apfel. Example: Er hat einen Hund.

sections.title: Feminine and neuter in accusative (basic)
sections.content: Feminine 'die' and neuter 'das' usually do not change in accusative at this level. Example: Ich sehe die Katze. Example: Ich habe das Buch.

topics.title: Regular & Separable Verbs
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Present Tense (Regular Verbs), Introduction to Reflexive Verbs, Inseparable Verbs, Noun-Verb Combinations

sections.title: --- Present Tense (Regular Verbs) ---
sections.content: Conjugate regular -en verbs in the present tense to talk about what happens now.

sections.title: Regular verb endings
sections.content: Regular verbs remove -en and add endings: ich -e, du -st, er/sie/es -t, wir -en, ihr -t, sie/Sie -en. Example: Ich lerne in der Schule. Example: Du spielst mit dem Kind.

sections.title: Example verb: machen
sections.content: Machen (to do/make): ich mache, du machst, er macht, wir machen, ihr macht, sie machen. Example: Ich mache die Tür zu. Example: Wir machen die Tür auf.

sections.title: Example verbs: lernen, spielen
sections.content: Lernen and spielen follow the same pattern. Example: Die Frau lernt Deutsch. Example: Das Kind spielt im Haus.

sections.title: --- Introduction to Reflexive Verbs ---
sections.content: Learn basic verbs where the action reflects back on the subject.

sections.title: What is a Reflexive Verb?
sections.content: A reflexive verb is used when the subject and the object are the same person. The action reflects back on the subject. For example: Ich wasche mich. (I wash myself.)

sections.title: Mich and Dich
sections.content: For ich, the reflexive pronoun in the accusative is mich. For du, it is dich. For example: Ich setze mich auf den Stuhl. Du freust dich.

sections.title: Sich for Third Person and Plural
sections.content: For er, sie, es, and the formal/plural Sie/sie, the reflexive pronoun is always sich. For example: Das Kind wäscht sich. Die Hunde waschen sich.

sections.title: --- Inseparable Verbs ---
sections.content: Learn about verbs with prefixes that do not split apart.

sections.title: Common Inseparable Prefixes
sections.content: Unlike separable verbs, some prefixes never break off from the main verb. The most common inseparable prefixes are be-, emp-, ent-, er-, ge-, ver-, and zer-. For example: Ich besuche den Mann. Die Frau versteht das Kind.

sections.title: Verb Position
sections.content: Because the prefix does not separate, the entire verb stays together in the second position of the sentence. For example: Wir verkaufen das Auto. Der Hund zerreißt das Buch.

sections.title: Past Participles
sections.content: When forming the perfect tense (past tense) with inseparable verbs, you do not add the 'ge-' prefix. For example: Ich habe das Haus verkauft. Er hat den Apfel bezahlt.

sections.title: --- Noun-Verb Combinations ---
sections.content: Learn common activities where a noun and a verb are used together without an article.

sections.title: Activities without Articles
sections.content: In German, many common hobbies and activities are formed by combining a noun directly with a verb. You do not use 'ein' or 'der/die/das'. For example: Wir fahren Rad (We ride bikes). Das Kind hört Musik (The child listens to music).

sections.title: Playing Instruments and Sports
sections.content: When talking about playing sports or musical instruments, always omit the article. For example: Ich spiele Klavier (I play piano). Der Mann spielt Fußball (The man plays football).

sections.title: Position in the Sentence
sections.content: These nouns act almost like separable prefixes. The noun goes to the very end of the sentence. For example: Er fährt heute mit dem Freund Rad. Sie hört im Haus laut Musik.

topics.title: Common Irregular Verbs
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Present Tense (Irregular Verbs: sein, haben, werden), The Verb 'tun' (To do), To Know: wissen vs. kennen, The Verb brauchen, The Verb lassen

sections.title: --- Present Tense (Irregular Verbs: sein, haben, werden) ---
sections.content: Use the most important irregular verbs in the present tense: sein, haben, and werden.

sections.title: sein (to be)
sections.content: Sein is irregular: ich bin, du bist, er/sie/es ist, wir sind, ihr seid, sie/Sie sind. Example: Ich bin in der Schule. Example: Der Hund ist im Haus.

sections.title: haben (to have)
sections.content: Haben is irregular: ich habe, du hast, er/sie/es hat, wir haben, ihr habt, sie/Sie haben. Example: Ich habe ein Buch. Example: Die Frau hat ein Auto.

sections.title: werden (to become / will)
sections.content: Werden is irregular: ich werde, du wirst, er/sie/es wird, wir werden, ihr werdet, sie/Sie werden. Example: Das Kind wird groß. Example: Ich werde müde.

sections.title: --- The Verb 'tun' (To do) ---
sections.content: Learn when to use the irregular verb tun instead of machen.

sections.title: Conjugation of tun
sections.content: The verb 'tun' (to do / to act) is highly irregular. The conjugation is: ich tue, du tust, er/sie/es tut, wir tun, ihr tut, sie/Sie tun. For example: Was tust du hier? Das Kind tut nichts.

sections.title: Tun vs. Machen
sections.content: 'Machen' means to make or produce something, while 'tun' is used for general actions or in fixed expressions. For example: Ich mache einen Apfelkuchen (I make an apple cake). Ich habe viel zu tun (I have a lot to do).

sections.title: Fixed Expressions with tun
sections.content: 'Tun' is often used in common phrases, like 'wehtun' (to hurt) or 'leid tun' (to be sorry). For example: Das tut mir leid. Der Fuß tut mir weh.

sections.title: --- To Know: wissen vs. kennen ---
sections.content: Learn the difference between knowing a fact and being familiar with a person or place.

sections.title: Kennen (To be familiar with)
sections.content: Use kennen when you are familiar with a person, place, or thing. It takes a direct object. For example: Ich kenne den Mann. Wir kennen die Stadt.

sections.title: Wissen (To know a fact)
sections.content: Use wissen for knowing information or facts. It is often used with question words or the word dass. For example: Ich weiß, wo das Haus ist. Er weiß das nicht.

sections.title: Conjugation of Wissen
sections.content: Wissen is irregular in the singular: ich weiß, du weißt, er/sie/es weiß. The plural is regular: wir wissen, ihr wisst, sie/Sie wissen. For example: Weißt du das? Die Frau weiß alles.

sections.title: --- The Verb brauchen ---
sections.content: Express needs using the verb brauchen and the accusative case.

sections.title: Meaning and Conjugation
sections.content: The verb 'brauchen' means to need. It is a completely regular verb. For example: Ich brauche ein Auto. Du brauchst Wasser.

sections.title: Brauchen + Accusative
sections.content: Because you are needing a direct object, 'brauchen' always requires the accusative case. Masculine 'der' becomes 'den', and 'ein' becomes 'einen'. For example: Wir brauchen den Tisch. Die Frau braucht einen Apfel.

sections.title: Brauchen vs. Müssen
sections.content: Use 'brauchen' when you need a noun (a thing). Use the modal verb 'müssen' when you need or have to do an action (a verb). For example: Ich brauche Milch. Ich muss Milch trinken.

sections.title: --- The Verb lassen ---
sections.content: Understand how to use lassen to mean 'to leave' or 'to let'.

sections.title: Lassen as 'to leave'
sections.content: 'Lassen' can mean leaving an object somewhere. It requires the accusative case. For example: Ich lasse das Buch auf dem Tisch. Er lässt den Hund im Haus.

sections.title: Lassen as 'to let/allow'
sections.content: It can also mean to let or to allow someone to do something. Like a modal verb, it pushes the second verb to the end as an infinitive. For example: Die Frau lässt das Kind spielen. Wir lassen die Katze schlafen.

sections.title: Conjugation of lassen
sections.content: The singular forms are irregular and take an Umlaut. 'ich lasse, du lässt, er/sie/es lässt'. Plural forms are regular. For example: Du lässt die Tür offen. Der Mann lässt das Auto hier.

exercises.explanation: Similar to modal verbs, 'lassen' sends the main infinitive verb to the end of the clause.

topics.title: Sentence Structure & Word Order
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Basic Sentence Structure, Time, Manner, Place (TeKaMoLo), Inversion in Main Clauses, Review: The Sentence Bracket, Adverbs of Sequence, Adverbs of Place, Adverbs of Time, Directional Adverbs: hin and her

sections.title: --- Basic Sentence Structure ---
sections.content: Build simple sentences with verb-second order, ask questions, and negate with nicht and kein.

sections.title: Statement word order (verb in position 2)
sections.content: In a normal statement, the conjugated verb is usually the second element. Example: Ich trinke Wasser. Example: Der Mann liest ein Buch.

sections.title: Yes/no questions (verb first)
sections.content: For yes/no questions, put the verb first. Example: Trinkst du Milch? Example: Hast du ein Buch?

sections.title: W-questions (question word first)
sections.content: For W-questions, the question word is first and the verb is second. Example: Wo ist die Schule? Example: Was trinkt die Frau?

sections.title: Negation with nicht and kein
sections.content: Use nicht to negate verbs/adjectives and kein to negate nouns (like ein/eine). Example: Ich bin nicht müde. Example: Ich habe kein Auto.

sections.title: --- Time, Manner, Place (TeKaMoLo) ---
sections.content: Learn the correct order of information in a German sentence.

sections.title: Time Before Place
sections.content: In German, expressions of time always come before expressions of place. For example: Ich lerne heute in der Schule. Wir spielen am Morgen im Haus.

sections.title: The TeKaMoLo Rule
sections.content: When a sentence has multiple details, they follow the order: Time (Wann?), Cause (Warum?), Manner (Wie?), Place (Wo?). We call this TeKaMoLo. For example: Der Mann fährt heute schnell in die Stadt. Die Katze läuft am Morgen leise durch die Straße.

sections.title: Putting Time First
sections.content: You can emphasize the time by putting it at the very beginning of the sentence. If you do this, the verb must still be in the second position, so the subject moves to position three. For example: Heute spiele ich mit dem Hund. Am Morgen trinkt das Mädchen Milch.

sections.title: --- Inversion in Main Clauses ---
sections.content: Learn how to switch the subject and verb to emphasize time or place.

sections.title: The Golden Rule: Verb in Position 2
sections.content: In a standard German statement, the conjugated verb is always the second idea in the sentence. The subject is usually first. For example: Ich trinke heute Wasser. Der Hund schläft hier.

sections.title: Starting with Time or Place
sections.content: You can emphasize when or where something happens by putting that information first. When you do this, the verb stays in position 2, so the subject must move to position 3. For example: Heute trinke ich Wasser. Hier schläft der Hund.

sections.title: Inverting with Objects
sections.content: You can even put the direct object first for emphasis. The rule stays the same: the verb is second, and the subject moves behind the verb. For example: Den Apfel esse ich. Das Buch liest die Frau.

sections.title: --- Review: The Sentence Bracket ---
sections.content: Review how German sentences split verbs to form a bracket around the information.

sections.title: The Core Concept
sections.content: A defining feature of German grammar is the 'Satzklammer' (Sentence Bracket). When a sentence has two verb parts, the conjugated verb sits in position 2, and the other part goes to the absolute end. All other information sits inside this bracket. For example: Ich *habe* gestern einen Apfel *gegessen*.

sections.title: Modal Verbs
sections.content: Modal verbs create a bracket with an infinitive at the end. For example: Der Mann *will* heute mit dem Hund *spielen*.

sections.title: Separable Verbs
sections.content: Separable prefixes create a bracket by breaking off and moving to the end. For example: Wir *kaufen* am Morgen im Supermarkt *ein*.

sections.title: --- Adverbs of Sequence ---
sections.content: Tell a story or describe your routine using words like first, then, and finally.

sections.title: Zuerst (First)
sections.content: To start a sequence of events, use 'zuerst'. It usually goes at the beginning of the sentence, which pushes the subject after the verb. For example: Zuerst trinke ich Wasser. Zuerst lese ich ein Buch.

sections.title: Dann and Danach (Then / After that)
sections.content: To continue the story, use 'dann' (then) or 'danach' (after that). They also cause the verb and subject to invert if placed at the start. For example: Dann esse ich einen Apfel. Danach gehe ich in die Schule.

sections.title: Zuletzt (Finally)
sections.content: To end the sequence, use 'zuletzt' or 'zum Schluss'. For example: Zuletzt spiele ich mit dem Hund. Zum Schluss schläft das Kind.

sections.title: --- Adverbs of Place ---
sections.content: Describe where things are using words like hier, dort, and da.

sections.title: Hier (Here)
sections.content: 'Hier' means here, close to the speaker. It is used to point out something nearby. For example: Das Buch ist hier. Wir bleiben heute hier.

sections.title: Dort and Da (There)
sections.content: 'Dort' and 'da' both mean there, pointing to something further away. 'Da' is very common in spoken German and can mean here or there depending on context. For example: Der Mann ist dort. Die Schule ist da drüben.

sections.title: Oben and Unten (Up and Down)
sections.content: 'Oben' means up or upstairs, and 'unten' means down or downstairs. For example: Das Kind spielt oben. Der Hund schläft unten.

sections.title: --- Adverbs of Time ---
sections.content: Talk about when things happen using gestern, heute, and morgen.

sections.title: Gestern, Heute, Morgen
sections.content: 'Gestern' means yesterday, 'heute' means today, and 'morgen' means tomorrow. For example: Heute lerne ich Deutsch. Morgen kaufe ich ein Buch. Gestern war der Mann hier.

sections.title: Jetzt and Später
sections.content: 'Jetzt' means now, and 'später' means later. For example: Jetzt trinke ich Milch. Wir spielen später mit dem Hund.

sections.title: Position in the Sentence
sections.content: Time adverbs often go at the very beginning of the sentence to show emphasis, or they go right after the conjugated verb. For example: Jetzt gehe ich in die Schule. Ich gehe jetzt in die Schule.

sections.title: --- Directional Adverbs: hin and her ---
sections.content: Indicate direction towards or away from the speaker.

sections.title: Her (Towards the speaker)
sections.content: 'Her' implies movement towards the person who is speaking. It acts like a separable prefix. For example: Komm her! (Come here!) Das Kind läuft her.

sections.title: Hin (Away from the speaker)
sections.content: 'Hin' implies movement away from the person speaking towards another location. For example: Geh hin! (Go there!) Die Frau schaut hin.

sections.title: Combining with Prepositions
sections.content: You can combine 'hin' and 'her' with prepositions like 'ein' (in) and 'aus' (out). 'Herein' means come in (towards me). 'Hinaus' means go out (away from me). For example: Komm bitte herein! Geh hinaus!

topics.title: Personal Pronouns (Nom / Acc / Dat)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Personal Pronouns, Accusative Personal Pronouns, Dative Personal Pronouns

sections.title: --- Personal Pronouns ---
sections.content: Use personal pronouns for people and things: ich, du, er/sie/es, wir, ihr, sie/Sie.

sections.title: Singular pronouns
sections.content: Use ich (I), du (you informal), er/sie/es (he/she/it). Example: Ich lerne Deutsch. Example: Er hat ein Buch.

sections.title: Plural pronouns
sections.content: Use wir (we), ihr (you plural informal), sie (they). Example: Wir trinken Wasser. Example: Ihr spielt in der Schule.

sections.title: Formal 'Sie'
sections.content: Use Sie to be polite with strangers; it uses the same verb form as 'sie' (they). Example: Sie kommen aus der Stadt. Example: Haben Sie ein Auto?

sections.title: --- Accusative Personal Pronouns ---
sections.content: Replace direct objects with pronouns like mich, dich, and ihn.

sections.title: Singular Pronouns
sections.content: When a person or thing is the direct object, the pronouns change to the accusative case. 'Ich' becomes 'mich', and 'du' becomes 'dich'. 'Er' becomes 'ihn', while 'sie' and 'es' stay the same. For example: Die Frau fragt mich. Der Mann sieht dich.

sections.title: Plural and Formal Pronouns
sections.content: For the plural forms, 'wir' becomes 'uns', and 'ihr' becomes 'euch'. The formal 'Sie' and plural 'sie' remain unchanged. For example: Der Freund sucht uns. Das Kind hört euch.

sections.title: Replacing Nouns in Sentences
sections.content: Pronouns are used so we do not have to repeat the noun. You must match the gender of the noun you are replacing. For example: Wo ist der Apfel? Ich esse ihn. Wo ist die Katze? Ich sehe sie.

sections.title: --- Dative Personal Pronouns ---
sections.content: Use personal pronouns as indirect objects with mir, dir, and ihm.

sections.title: Singular Pronouns in Dative
sections.content: When a pronoun is the indirect object, it must be in the dative case. 'Ich' becomes 'mir', and 'du' becomes 'dir'. 'Er' and 'es' become 'ihm', and 'sie' becomes 'ihr'. For example: Das Buch gehört mir. Der Hund folgt dir.

sections.title: Plural Pronouns in Dative
sections.content: The plural pronouns 'wir' and 'ihr' become 'uns' and 'euch', just like in the accusative. The plural 'sie' becomes 'ihnen'. For example: Die Frau hilft uns. Das Mädchen dankt euch.

sections.title: Using Dative Verbs
sections.content: Remember that certain verbs always require the dative case, even if they seem like direct objects in English. Examples include helfen, danken, and gefallen. For example: Das Auto gefällt ihm. Die Milch schmeckt ihr.

topics.title: Possession (mein / dein / sein...)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Possessive Articles (mein, dein, sein, ihr), Possessive Articles in Accusative, Possessive Names

sections.title: --- Possessive Articles (mein, dein, sein, ihr) ---
sections.content: Use possessive articles to show ownership, like my/your/his/her.

sections.title: mein and dein (my/your)
sections.content: Possessive articles come before the noun and behave like ein/eine in simple forms. Example: Mein Hund ist groß. Example: Deine Katze ist klein.

sections.title: sein and ihr (his/her/their)
sections.content: Use sein for 'his' (and often 'its') and ihr for 'her' (and also 'their'). Example: Sein Buch ist auf dem Tisch. Example: Ihr Auto ist in der Stadt.

sections.title: Simple sentences with possessives
sections.content: Put the possessive before the noun in everyday sentences. Example: Dein Haus ist groß. Example: Mein Freund ist in der Schule.

sections.title: --- Possessive Articles in Accusative ---
sections.content: Use possessive articles correctly when they are the direct object.

sections.title: Masculine in Accusative
sections.content: Just like the indefinite article 'einen', possessive articles for masculine direct objects end in -en. For example: Ich sehe meinen Hund. Die Frau kauft ihren Tisch.

sections.title: Feminine and Neuter in Accusative
sections.content: Feminine and neuter possessive articles do not change in the accusative case. They stay exactly the same as in the nominative. For example: Er liebt seine Katze. Wir sehen unser Auto.

sections.title: Plural in Accusative
sections.content: Plural possessive articles also remain unchanged in the accusative case, ending in -e. For example: Die Kinder lesen ihre Bücher. Ich trinke meine Milch.

sections.title: --- Possessive Names ---
sections.content: Express ownership using people's names.

sections.title: Adding an -s
sections.content: To say something belongs to someone, simply add an 's' to their name. In German, you do not use an apostrophe. For example: Das ist Annas Hund. Peters Katze trinkt Milch.

sections.title: Names Ending in S-Sounds
sections.content: If a name ends in an s, z, or x, you cannot add another 's'. Instead, add an apostrophe at the end of the name. For example: Das ist Max' Auto. Hans' Buch ist neu.

sections.title: Using von + Dative
sections.content: In spoken German, it is very common to use the word 'von' (from/of) plus the dative case to show possession instead of adding an 's'. For example: Das ist das Haus von Anna. Der Hund von Max ist groß.

topics.title: Prepositions (Acc / Dat / Two-Way)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Prepositions with Accusative (durch, für, gegen, ohne, um), Two-Way Prepositions (in, an, auf), The Preposition seit (Since/For), Materials with 'aus', Destinations: nach, in, zu, Home: zu Hause vs. nach Hause

sections.title: --- Prepositions with Accusative (durch, für, gegen, ohne, um) ---
sections.content: Use these prepositions with the accusative case for the noun that follows.

sections.title: durch and um
sections.content: After durch and um, the noun is accusative. Example: Der Mann geht durch die Stadt. Example: Wir laufen um das Haus.

sections.title: für (for)
sections.content: Für means 'for' and needs accusative after it. Example: Ich kaufe einen Apfel für den Freund. Example: Das Wasser ist für das Kind.

sections.title: gegen and ohne
sections.content: Gegen means 'against' and ohne means 'without'; both take accusative. Example: Der Hund läuft gegen die Tür. Example: Ich gehe ohne den Freund in die Stadt.

sections.title: --- Two-Way Prepositions (in, an, auf) ---
sections.content: Use accusative for movement (where to?) and dative for location (where?) with in, an, and auf.

sections.title: Where? vs. where to?
sections.content: Two-way prepositions can use accusative or dative depending on meaning: location (Wo?) = dative, movement (Wohin?) = accusative. Example: Das Buch ist auf dem Tisch. Example: Ich lege das Buch auf den Tisch.

sections.title: in with city, house, school
sections.content: Use in + dative for location and in + accusative for movement. Example: Ich bin in der Schule. Example: Ich gehe in die Schule. Example: Der Hund ist im Haus. Example: Der Hund läuft in das Haus.

sections.title: an and auf in simple contexts
sections.content: An can be used for being at something (like a door), and auf for being on something (like a table). Example: Der Mann steht an der Tür. Example: Der Mann geht an die Tür. Example: Die Milch steht auf dem Tisch. Example: Ich stelle die Milch auf den Tisch.

sections.title: --- The Preposition seit (Since/For) ---
sections.content: Talk about ongoing events using seit with the dative case.

sections.title: Meaning of seit
sections.content: Seit means both since (a point in time) and for (a duration of time). It connects an action from the past to the present. For example: Ich lerne seit einem Jahr Deutsch. Ich lebe seit Montag hier.

sections.title: Seit Requires Dative
sections.content: Seit always forces the noun that follows it into the dative case. For example: Seit dem Morgen regnet es. Seit der Schule bin ich müde.

sections.title: Used with the Present Tense
sections.content: Unlike English, which uses the present perfect (I have been learning), German uses the present tense with seit for things that are still happening. For example: Er wohnt seit einem Monat in der Stadt.

sections.title: --- Materials with 'aus' ---
sections.content: Describe what objects are made of using the preposition aus.

sections.title: Using 'aus' for Materials
sections.content: To say what something is made of, use the verb 'sein' (to be) followed by the preposition 'aus' and the material. You do not use an article. For example: Der Tisch ist aus Holz (wood). Das Fenster ist aus Glas (glass).

sections.title: Common Materials
sections.content: Important material words include Holz (wood), Glas (glass), Plastik (plastic), Papier (paper), and Metall (metal). For example: Das Buch ist aus Papier. Das Auto ist aus Metall.

sections.title: Asking 'Woraus?'
sections.content: To ask what something is made of, use the question word 'Woraus' (out of what). For example: Woraus ist der Stuhl? Er ist aus Plastik.

sections.title: --- Destinations: nach, in, zu ---
sections.content: Know exactly which preposition to use when going to a place.

sections.title: Nach for Cities and Countries
sections.content: Use 'nach' when traveling to a city, continent, or a country that does not have a feminine or plural article. For example: Ich fahre nach Berlin. Wir fliegen nach Deutschland. Er geht nach Europa.

sections.title: In for Enclosed Spaces and Exceptions
sections.content: Use 'in' (with the accusative case) for buildings, enclosed spaces, and countries with articles (like die Schweiz or die USA). For example: Das Kind geht in die Schule. Wir fliegen in die USA. Ich gehe ins Haus.

sections.title: Zu for People and Local Places
sections.content: Use 'zu' (with the dative case) when going to a person, a professional, or a specific local spot. For example: Ich gehe zum Bahnhof (to the station). Sie geht zur Ärztin (to the doctor). Wir fahren zu Peter.

sections.title: --- Home: zu Hause vs. nach Hause ---
sections.content: Learn the special phrases for being at home and going home.

sections.title: Zu Hause (At home)
sections.content: When you are already at your house (location), use the phrase 'zu Hause'. You do not need an article. For example: Ich bin zu Hause. Der Hund schläft zu Hause.

sections.title: Nach Hause (Going home)
sections.content: When you are traveling towards your house (movement), use the phrase 'nach Hause'. For example: Wir gehen nach Hause. Die Frau fährt nach Hause.

sections.title: Using with other verbs
sections.content: These phrases stay the same regardless of the verb, as long as the distinction between location and movement is clear. For example: Das Kind bleibt zu Hause. Er kommt bald nach Hause.

topics.title: Modal Verbs
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Modal Verbs (können, müssen, wollen, dürfen, sollen), Modal Verbs in the Past Tense

sections.title: --- Modal Verbs (können, müssen, wollen, dürfen, sollen) ---
sections.content: Use modal verbs to express ability, need, desire, permission, or advice, with a second verb at the end.

sections.title: Modal verb structure
sections.content: A modal verb is conjugated, and the main verb goes to the end in the infinitive. Example: Ich kann Deutsch lernen. Example: Der Mann muss Wasser trinken.

sections.title: können, müssen, wollen
sections.content: These modals are very common for daily life: can, must, want. Example: Du kannst das Buch lesen. Example: Wir wollen in die Stadt gehen.

sections.title: dürfen and sollen
sections.content: dürfen means allowed to, and sollen means should. Example: Das Kind darf im Haus spielen. Example: Ich soll in die Schule gehen.

sections.title: --- Modal Verbs in the Past Tense ---
sections.content: Learn how to use modal verbs in the simple past.

sections.title: Wollen to Wollte
sections.content: In spoken German, modal verbs are almost always used in the simple past rather than the perfect tense. 'Wollen' (to want) becomes 'wollte'. For example: Ich wollte einen Apfel. Er wollte im Haus spielen.

sections.title: Können to Konnte
sections.content: 'Können' (can) loses its Umlaut and becomes 'konnte' (could). For example: Ich konnte Deutsch sprechen. Wir konnten der Frau helfen.

sections.title: Müssen to Musste
sections.content: 'Müssen' (must) loses its Umlaut and becomes 'musste' (had to). For example: Das Kind musste schlafen. Sie mussten Wasser trinken.

exercises.explanation: 'Konnte' is the simple past form of 'können', dropping the Umlaut.

exercises.explanation: 'Musste' is the past tense of 'müssen'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Der Mann ___ ein Auto kaufen (wanted to).
exercises.explanation: 'Wollte' is the simple past form of 'wollen'.

topics.title: Separable Verbs (aufstehen, anfangen, einkaufen)
topics.description: Learn verbs with prefixes that split off in main sentences and move to the end.

sections.title: Separable verb rule
sections.content: In main sentences, the conjugated verb is in position 2 and the prefix goes to the end. Example: Ich stehe um 7 Uhr auf. Example: Der Mann fängt um 8 Uhr an.

sections.title: aufstehen and anfangen in daily life
sections.content: You can talk about routines with separable verbs. Example: Das Kind steht früh auf. Example: Wir fangen in der Schule an.

sections.title: einkaufen with objects
sections.content: Einkaufen is common for shopping; you can add objects after the verb. Example: Ich kaufe Milch ein. Example: Sie kauft Wasser und einen Apfel ein.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich ___ um 7 Uhr auf.
exercises.explanation: With 'ich', 'aufstehen' becomes 'stehe … auf'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Er ___ um 8 Uhr an.
exercises.explanation: With 'er', 'anfangen' becomes 'fängt … an'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Wir kaufen Milch ___.
exercises.explanation: The prefix 'ein' goes to the end: 'kaufen … ein'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Das Kind ___ früh auf.
exercises.explanation: With 'das Kind' (3rd person singular), use 'steht'.

topics.title: The Dative Case (Intro)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Introduction to the Dative Case, Dative Verbs

sections.title: --- Introduction to the Dative Case ---
sections.content: Use the dative case mainly for indirect objects, often with articles like dem, der, dem.

sections.title: Indirect object = dative
sections.content: The indirect object answers: to whom/for whom? It is often dative. Example: Ich gebe dem Mann das Buch. Example: Sie gibt der Frau den Apfel.

sections.title: Dative definite articles (singular)
sections.content: In singular dative: dem (m.), der (f.), dem (n.). Example: Das Buch ist bei dem Mann. Example: Die Milch ist bei der Frau.

sections.title: Dative in simple giving sentences
sections.content: A common pattern is: subject + verb + dative person + accusative thing. Example: Wir geben dem Kind Wasser. Example: Ich gebe dem Freund das Buch.

sections.title: --- Dative Verbs ---
sections.content: Learn common verbs that always take the dative case.

sections.title: Helfen (to help)
sections.content: Some verbs always require the dative case instead of the accusative. Helfen is a very common dative verb. For example: Ich helfe dem Mann. Die Frau hilft dem Kind.

sections.title: Danken (to thank)
sections.content: When you thank someone, the person you are thanking must be in the dative case. For example: Ich danke dem Freund. Wir danken der Lehrerin.

sections.title: Gefallen (to be pleasing / to like)
sections.content: Gefallen is used to say that you like something, but literally it means 'to be pleasing to'. The thing you like is the subject, and you are the dative object. For example: Das Auto gefällt dem Mann. Das Buch gefällt der Frau.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich gebe ___ Mann das Buch.
exercises.explanation: Mann is masculine; in dative it uses 'dem'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Sie gibt ___ Frau den Apfel.
exercises.explanation: Frau is feminine; in dative it uses 'der'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Wir geben ___ Kind Wasser.
exercises.explanation: Kind is neuter; in dative it uses 'dem'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Der Hund ist bei ___ Mann.
exercises.explanation: Bei takes dative; Mann is masculine, so it uses 'dem'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Das Kind hilft ___ Frau.
exercises.explanation: Helfen requires the dative case, and die Frau becomes der Frau.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich danke ___ Freund (masculine).
exercises.explanation: Danken takes the dative case, so masculine der becomes dem.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Das Haus gefällt ___ Hund.
exercises.explanation: Gefallen takes the dative case, so masculine der becomes dem.

topics.title: Prepositions Dative
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Prepositions with Dative, Prepositions with Dative

sections.title: --- Prepositions with Dative ---
sections.content: Learn common prepositions that always take the dative: aus, bei, mit, nach, seit, von, zu.

sections.title: Dative after certain prepositions
sections.content: Some prepositions always need the dative case for the noun after them. Example: Ich komme aus der Stadt. Example: Das Kind geht zu der Schule.

sections.title: mit, bei, von in everyday sentences
sections.content: Use mit (with), bei (at/with), and von (from) with dative articles. Example: Ich bin mit dem Freund in der Stadt. Example: Die Frau ist bei der Schule. Example: Das Buch ist von dem Mann.

sections.title: nach, zu, seit for direction and time
sections.content: Use nach (to, for cities/countries), zu (to, for people/places), and seit (since). Example: Wir fahren nach Berlin. Example: Ich gehe zu dem Freund. Example: Ich lerne seit einem Monat Deutsch.

sections.title: --- Prepositions with Dative ---
sections.content: Learn the prepositions that always require the dative case.

sections.title: Mit and Nach
sections.content: Mit means with, and nach means after or to (for cities/countries). They always take the dative case. Remember: der/das become dem, and die becomes der. For example: Ich spiele mit dem Hund. Wir gehen nach der Schule nach Hause.

sections.title: Aus and Von
sections.content: Aus means out of or from (a country/place), and von means from (a person/thing). For example: Das Kind kommt aus dem Haus. Das Buch ist von der Frau.

sections.title: Bei and Zu
sections.content: Bei means at or near, and zu means to (a local place or person). Zu dem contracts to zum, and zu der contracts to zur. For example: Ich bin bei dem Freund. Er geht zur Schule.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich gehe mit ___ Mann.
exercises.explanation: Mit always takes dative; Mann is masculine, so it uses 'dem'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Sie kommt aus ___ Stadt.
exercises.explanation: Aus always takes dative; Stadt is feminine, so it uses 'der'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Wir gehen zu ___ Schule.
exercises.explanation: Zu always takes dative; Schule is feminine, so it uses 'der'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich trinke Kaffee mit ___ Milch (feminine).
exercises.explanation: Mit requires dative, so feminine die becomes der.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Das Auto kommt aus ___ Wald (masculine).
exercises.explanation: Aus requires dative, so masculine der becomes dem.

exercises.question: What is the contraction for 'zu dem'?
exercises.explanation: Zu + dem merges into the short form zum.

topics.title: The Past Tense (Perfekt & Präteritum)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: The Perfect Tense, Simple Past: sein and haben, Expressing the Future

sections.title: --- The Perfect Tense ---
sections.content: Learn to talk about the past using the conversational perfect tense.

sections.title: Forming the Perfect Tense
sections.content: In spoken German, we use the perfect tense to talk about the past. It is built with a helper verb (haben or sein) in the second position and a past participle at the very end of the sentence. For example: Ich habe ein Buch gekauft.

sections.title: Regular Past Participles
sections.content: For regular verbs, the past participle usually starts with ge- and ends with -t. For example, machen becomes gemacht, and spielen becomes gespielt. For example: Das Kind hat gespielt. Wir haben Musik gemacht.

sections.title: Using sein as a Helper Verb
sections.content: Most verbs use haben as the helper verb. However, verbs that show movement from A to B (like gehen to go, or kommen to come) use sein. For example: Ich bin nach Hause gegangen. Die Frau ist gekommen.

sections.title: --- Simple Past: sein and haben ---
sections.content: Learn to talk about the past using war and hatte.

sections.title: The Past Tense of sein (was/were)
sections.content: To say was or were, use the past tense of sein, which is war. The conjugation is: ich war, du warst, er/sie/es war, wir waren, ihr wart, sie/Sie waren. For example: Der Hund war gestern klein. Die Frau war in der Stadt.

sections.title: The Past Tense of haben (had)
sections.content: To say had, use the past tense of haben, which is hatte. The conjugation is: ich hatte, du hattest, er/sie/es hatte, wir hatten, ihr hattet, sie/Sie hatten. For example: Ich hatte eine Katze. Der Mann hatte ein Buch.

sections.title: Usage in Sentences
sections.content: Unlike other verbs that use the perfect tense in spoken German, sein and haben are almost always used in their simple past forms (war and hatte). For example: Wir waren in der Schule. Das Kind hatte Milch.

sections.title: --- Expressing the Future ---
sections.content: Use the present tense with time words to talk about future events.

sections.title: Present Tense for the Future
sections.content: In German, you can easily use the present tense to talk about the future, as long as the context is clear. For example: Ich spiele morgen Fußball. Wir fliegen bald.

sections.title: Time Words
sections.content: Using words like morgen (tomorrow) or bald (soon) shows that the action is in the future without changing the verb tense. For example: Morgen kaufe ich ein Auto. Er kommt bald nach Hause.

sections.title: Introduction to Werden
sections.content: You can also use the helper verb werden (to become) plus an infinitive at the end to express the formal future tense. For example: Ich werde ein Buch lesen. Das Mädchen wird Wasser trinken.

exercises.question: Where does the past participle go in a German sentence?
options: At the very end of the sentence
exercises.answer: At the very end of the sentence
exercises.explanation: The helper verb takes the second position, and the past participle is pushed to the very end.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Er ___ ein Auto gekauft.
exercises.explanation: Kaufen (to buy) takes haben, and the er form is hat.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Wir ___ in die Stadt gegangen.
exercises.explanation: Gehen (to go) shows movement, so it uses sein. The wir form is sind.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich ___ gestern müde.
exercises.explanation: War is the ich form of the simple past of sein.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Er ___ einen Hund.
exercises.explanation: Hatte is the er form of the simple past of haben.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Wir ___ in der Schule.
exercises.explanation: Waren is the wir form of the simple past of sein.

exercises.question: How do you usually express future plans in everyday spoken German?
options: With the present tense + a time word
exercises.answer: With the present tense + a time word
exercises.explanation: The present tense is commonly used for future events when a time word provides context.

exercises.question: Translate: 'Tomorrow I am buying a dog.'
exercises.explanation: This sentence perfectly uses the present tense + morgen to indicate the future.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank to build the formal future tense: Wir ___ in die Stadt gehen.
exercises.explanation: The auxiliary verb werden is used with an infinitive to build the future tense.

topics.title: Imperative Mood (Commands)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: The Imperative Mood, Imperative (Commands), Making Suggestions (Let's...)

sections.title: --- The Imperative Mood ---
sections.content: Learn how to give commands and make requests in German.

sections.title: The Informal Singular (du)
sections.content: To give a command to one person you know well, take the du form of the verb and remove the -st ending. You also drop the word du. For example: Mach die Tür zu! (Close the door!) Trink das Wasser! (Drink the water!)

sections.title: The Informal Plural (ihr)
sections.content: To give a command to a group of friends or children, use the ihr form but drop the word ihr. The verb ends in -t. For example: Macht die Tür zu! Lernt Deutsch!

sections.title: The Formal Command (Sie)
sections.content: To give a formal command, use the infinitive verb followed by the word Sie. This is used for strangers or authority figures. For example: Machen Sie die Tür zu! Trinken Sie den Kaffee!

sections.title: --- Imperative (Commands) ---
sections.content: Give simple commands with du, ihr, and Sie forms like Komm!, Kommt!, and Kommen Sie!

sections.title: du-commands (informal singular)
sections.content: For du-commands, use a short verb form (often without -st). Example: Komm in die Schule! Example: Mach die Tür zu!

sections.title: ihr-commands (informal plural)
sections.content: For ihr-commands, use the ihr verb form (often ending in -t). Example: Kommt in die Stadt! Example: Trinkt Wasser!

sections.title: Sie-commands (formal)
sections.content: For polite commands, use the Sie form and keep Sie in the sentence. Example: Kommen Sie bitte zur Schule! Example: Machen Sie die Tür zu!

sections.title: --- Making Suggestions (Let's...) ---
sections.content: Learn how to suggest doing something together using the wir-form.

sections.title: The 'Wir' Imperative
sections.content: To say 'Let's do something' in German, put the infinitive verb in the first position, followed immediately by 'wir'. For example: Gehen wir nach Hause! Trinken wir Wasser!

sections.title: Adding 'mal' or 'doch'
sections.content: You can add small flavor words (particles) like 'mal' or 'doch' to make the suggestion sound friendlier and more natural. For example: Spielen wir mal Fußball! Kaufen wir doch das Auto!

sections.title: Questions as Suggestions
sections.content: You can also make a suggestion by asking a question with 'sollen' (should). For example: Sollen wir einen Apfel essen? Sollen wir in die Stadt gehen?

exercises.question: How do you say 'Come!' to one friend?
exercises.explanation: Drop the -st from du kommst and drop the pronoun.

exercises.question: How do you say 'Drink!' to a group of friends?
exercises.explanation: Use the ihr form (trinkt) but do not say the pronoun.

exercises.question: How do you formally ask someone to 'Learn'?
exercises.explanation: Formal commands use the full infinitive verb followed by Sie.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ die Tür zu! (du)
exercises.explanation: For a du-command, use the short form: Mach!

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ Wasser! (ihr)
exercises.explanation: For an ihr-command, use the ihr form: Trinkt!

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ bitte zur Schule! (Sie)
exercises.explanation: For a formal command, use 'Kommen Sie'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ das Buch! (du)
exercises.explanation: For a du-command with lesen, use the short form: Lies!

exercises.question: How do you say 'Let's go!'?
exercises.explanation: Start with the infinitive verb followed by 'wir' to make a suggestion.

exercises.question: Translate: 'Let's drink milk!'
exercises.explanation: The verb comes first, followed by 'wir', and then the object.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank for a friendly suggestion: ___ wir nach Hause gehen?
exercises.explanation: 'Sollen wir...' is a common way to ask 'Should we...' or 'Shall we...'.

topics.title: Asking Questions (W-Words, Yes/No)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Question Words (Wer, Was, Wo, Wann, Wie), The Question Word 'welcher', Asking 'What kind of...?', Answering Negative Questions (doch)

sections.title: --- Question Words (Wer, Was, Wo, Wann, Wie) ---
sections.content: Ask simple questions with common question words and keep the verb in position 2.

sections.title: Wer and Was
sections.content: Wer asks about a person (who) and Was asks about a thing (what). Example: Wer ist der Mann? Example: Was ist das? Example: Wer hat das Buch? Example: Was trinkt die Frau?

sections.title: Wo, Wohin, Woher
sections.content: Wo asks location, Wohin asks direction, and Woher asks origin. Example: Wo ist die Schule? Example: Wohin geht das Kind? Example: Woher kommst du? Example: Ich komme aus der Stadt.

sections.title: Wann and Wie
sections.content: Wann asks time and Wie asks manner or name. Example: Wann fängt die Schule an? Example: Wann kommst du nach Hause? Example: Wie heißt du? Example: Wie geht es dem Kind?

sections.title: --- The Question Word 'welcher' ---
sections.content: Ask 'which one' using welcher, welche, and welches.

sections.title: Masculine and Neuter
sections.content: To ask 'which' in German, you must match the gender of the noun. For masculine nouns, use 'welcher'. For neuter nouns, use 'welches'. For example: Welcher Hund bellt? Welches Auto ist schnell?

sections.title: Feminine and Plural
sections.content: For feminine nouns and all plural nouns, use 'welche'. For example: Welche Frau liest das Buch? Welche Kinder spielen hier?

sections.title: In the Accusative Case
sections.content: Just like the article 'der' becomes 'den', 'welcher' changes to 'welchen' when it is the direct object. For example: Welchen Apfel isst du? Welchen Tisch kaufst du?

sections.title: --- Asking 'What kind of...?' ---
sections.content: Learn how to ask what type or kind of something using 'Was für ein'.

sections.title: The Phrase 'Was für ein'
sections.content: To ask 'What kind of' or 'What sort of', German uses the phrase 'Was für ein'. The 'ein' changes depending on the gender of the noun. For example: Was für ein Hund ist das? Was für eine Katze hast du?

sections.title: In the Accusative Case
sections.content: If the noun you are asking about is the direct object, the 'ein' must change to the accusative case. Masculine becomes 'einen'. For example: Was für einen Apfel isst du? Was für ein Auto kaufst du?

sections.title: Plural and Uncountable Nouns
sections.content: For plural nouns or uncountable things (like water or milk), you drop the 'ein' entirely and just use 'Was für'. For example: Was für Bücher liest die Frau? Was für Wasser trinkt das Kind?

sections.title: --- Answering Negative Questions (doch) ---
sections.content: Use the word doch to answer 'yes' to a negative question.

sections.title: Yes and No
sections.content: Normally, you answer a question with ja (yes) or nein (no). For example: Hast du einen Hund? Ja, ich habe einen Hund. Nein, ich habe keinen Hund.

sections.title: The Magic of doch
sections.content: If someone asks a question with a negative word (like nicht or kein), and you want to contradict them and say 'Actually, yes!', you must use the word doch. For example: Hast du keinen Hund? Doch! Ich habe einen Hund.

sections.title: Contradicting Statements
sections.content: You can also use doch to correct a negative statement someone makes. For example: Das Auto ist nicht schnell. Doch, das Auto ist sehr schnell!

exercises.explanation: 'Wo' means 'where' for location.

exercises.explanation: 'Wer' means 'who' for a person.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ kommst du? (From where?)
exercises.explanation: 'Woher' means 'from where'.

exercises.explanation: 'Hund' is masculine, so 'welcher' is used in the nominative case.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ Katze schläft? (feminine)
exercises.explanation: 'Katze' is feminine, so 'welche' is used.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ Apfel kaufst du? (masculine, direct object)
exercises.explanation: Because the apple is the direct object (accusative case), 'welcher' changes to 'welchen'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Was für ___ Haus ist das? (neuter)
exercises.explanation: 'Haus' is neuter, so 'ein' is the correct form in the nominative case.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Was für ___ Tisch kaufst du? (masculine, accusative)
exercises.explanation: 'Tisch' is the direct object being bought, so 'ein' becomes 'einen'.

exercises.question: How do you ask 'What kind of dogs?' (plural)
exercises.explanation: Drop the 'ein' completely when asking about plural nouns.

exercises.question: How do you answer 'yes' to the question: 'Trinkst du kein Wasser?'
exercises.explanation: Because the question contains the negative word 'kein', you must use 'doch' to say 'Yes, I do'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Das Kind isst den Apfel nicht. - ___, es isst den Apfel!
exercises.explanation: Use 'doch' to contradict a negative statement.

exercises.question: If someone asks 'Kommst du heute?', how do you say yes?
exercises.explanation: Since there is no negative word in the question, a simple 'Ja' is correct.

topics.title: Time, Dates & Years
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Time Expressions, Time Expressions (heute, morgen, um, am), Dates and Ordinal Numbers, Reading Years, Telling Time (Informal), Review: Days, Months, and Seasons, Time Prepositions (ab, bis, von... bis)

sections.title: --- Time Expressions ---
sections.content: Express when things happen using um, am, and im.

sections.title: Clock Time with um
sections.content: To say at a specific clock time, use the preposition um. For example: Der Unterricht beginnt um acht Uhr. Ich schlafe um zehn Uhr.

sections.title: Days and Parts of the Day with am
sections.content: To say on a day of the week or in a part of the day, use am (an + dem). For example: Am Montag lerne ich Deutsch. Am Morgen trinke ich Wasser. Note: The exception is in der Nacht (at night).

sections.title: Months and Seasons with im
sections.content: To say in a month or in a season, use im (in + dem). For example: Im Sommer ist es heiß. Im Mai gehen wir spazieren.

sections.title: --- Time Expressions (heute, morgen, um, am) ---
sections.content: Talk about time with words like heute/morgen and phrases like um 7 Uhr and am Montag.

sections.title: heute and morgen
sections.content: Heute means today and morgen means tomorrow; they often go near the beginning of the sentence. Example: Heute trinke ich Wasser. Example: Morgen kaufe ich Milch.

sections.title: um + clock time
sections.content: Use um with a clock time to say when something happens. Example: Ich gehe um 8 Uhr in die Schule. Example: Der Mann steht um 7 Uhr auf.

sections.title: am + day (and simple parts of the day)
sections.content: Use am with days: am Montag, am Dienstag; you can also use am Morgen/am Abend in simple sentences. Example: Am Montag lernt das Kind in der Schule. Example: Am Dienstag spielt der Hund im Haus.

sections.title: --- Dates and Ordinal Numbers ---
sections.content: Learn how to use ordinal numbers to state the date.

sections.title: Ordinal Numbers 1st to 19th
sections.content: To form an ordinal number from 1 to 19, usually add -te to the number. Exceptions are erste (1st), dritte (3rd), and siebte (7th). For example: Der erste Apfel ist rot. Das dritte Auto ist schnell.

sections.title: Ordinal Numbers 20th and Above
sections.content: For numbers 20 and higher, add -ste. For example: der zwanzigste (20th), der einundzwanzigste (21st). For example: Heute ist der zwanzigste Tag. Der Mann kauft das dreißigste Buch.

sections.title: Saying the Date with am
sections.content: When saying something happens on a specific date, use the preposition am and add an -n to the ordinal number. For example: Am ersten Mai kaufe ich das Haus. Am dritten Juli trinke ich Wasser.

sections.title: --- Reading Years ---
sections.content: Learn how to pronounce years in German correctly.

sections.title: Years before 2000
sections.content: For years between 1100 and 1999, you count the hundreds. For example, 1995 is read as 'neunzehnhundertfünfundneunzig' (nineteen hundred five and ninety). For example: Das Haus ist von neunzehnhundertachtzig (1980).

sections.title: Years 2000 and after
sections.content: From the year 2000 onwards, you read the numbers like regular thousands. For example, 2010 is 'zweitausendzehn'. 2025 is 'zweitausendfünfundzwanzig'. For example: Das Kind ist zweitausendzehn geboren.

sections.title: Saying 'In the year...'
sections.content: In German, you never use the word 'in' alone before a year. You either use nothing at all, or the phrase 'im Jahr'. For example: Ich bin 1990 geboren. Oder: Ich bin im Jahr 1990 geboren.

sections.title: --- Telling Time (Informal) ---
sections.content: Learn how to tell time in everyday conversation using vor, nach, and halb.

sections.title: Viertel vor and Viertel nach
sections.content: To say quarter past or quarter to, use Viertel nach and Viertel vor. For example: Es ist Viertel nach drei (3:15). Es ist Viertel vor vier (3:45).

sections.title: Halb (Half past)
sections.content: In German, halb looks ahead to the next hour, meaning half to. For example: Es ist halb fünf means it is half way to five, so it is 4:30. Es ist halb acht is 7:30.

sections.title: Vor and Nach for Minutes
sections.content: For other minutes, use vor (before) and nach (after/past). For example: Es ist zehn nach zwei (2:10). Es ist fünf vor zwölf (11:55).

sections.title: --- Review: Days, Months, and Seasons ---
sections.content: Review the calendar and the correct prepositions to use for time.

sections.title: Days of the Week with am
sections.content: All days of the week are masculine (der). Always use the preposition am (an + dem) with days. For example: Montag, Dienstag, Mittwoch, Donnerstag, Freitag, Samstag, Sonntag. Am Montag lerne ich Deutsch.

sections.title: Months of the Year with im
sections.content: All months are also masculine. Always use the preposition im (in + dem) with months. For example: Januar, Februar, März, April... Im Mai ist es schön.

sections.title: Seasons with im
sections.content: The four seasons are masculine as well: der Frühling, der Sommer, der Herbst, der Winter. Use im. For example: Im Winter ist es kalt. Im Sommer spielen die Kinder im Haus.

sections.title: --- Time Prepositions (ab, bis, von... bis) ---
sections.content: Express starting points and durations using ab, bis, and von... bis.

sections.title: Ab (From a point in time)
sections.content: Use 'ab' to mean 'starting from' a specific time in the present or future. It usually takes the dative case. For example: Ab morgen lerne ich Deutsch. Ab dem Abend bin ich zu Hause.

sections.title: Bis (Until)
sections.content: Use 'bis' to mean 'until' a certain time or day. It does not usually require an article before days or months. For example: Wir warten bis Montag. Das Kind schläft bis neun Uhr.

sections.title: Von... bis (From... to)
sections.content: To express a duration between two points, use 'von... bis'. For example: Die Schule ist von acht bis zwölf Uhr. Ich arbeite von Montag bis Freitag.

exercises.explanation: Use am for days of the week.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Der Bus kommt ___ neun Uhr.
exercises.explanation: Use um for specific clock times.

exercises.explanation: Use im for seasons and months.

topics.title: Negation (nicht / kein)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Negation with kein and nicht, Detailed Negation (nicht vs. kein), Something, Nothing, and Everything

sections.title: --- Negation with kein and nicht ---
sections.content: Choose kein to negate nouns and nicht to negate verbs, adjectives, or specific information.

sections.title: kein negates nouns
sections.content: Use kein like ein/eine to mean 'no' or 'not a' with nouns. Example: Ich habe kein Auto. Example: Sie hat keine Katze.

sections.title: nicht negates verbs and adjectives
sections.content: Use nicht to say 'not' with verbs and adjectives. Example: Ich trinke nicht Milch. Example: Der Hund ist nicht klein. Example: Die Tür ist nicht offen. Example: Das Kind ist nicht müde.

sections.title: kein changes with gender and case
sections.content: Kein follows article patterns: masculine accusative is keinen. Example: Ich sehe keinen Hund. Example: Ich kaufe keinen Apfel.

sections.title: --- Detailed Negation (nicht vs. kein) ---
sections.content: Master the rules for negating nouns and verbs in German.

sections.title: Negating Nouns with kein
sections.content: Always use 'kein' to negate a noun that has an indefinite article (ein/eine) or no article at all. It takes the same endings as 'ein'. For example: Das ist kein Hund. Wir haben keine Katze.

sections.title: Negating Verbs and Adjectives with nicht
sections.content: Use 'nicht' to negate a verb or an adjective. For example: Ich schlafe nicht. Das Auto ist nicht schnell.

sections.title: Position of nicht
sections.content: When negating an entire sentence, 'nicht' goes to the very end. However, if there is a prepositional phrase, 'nicht' goes right before it. For example: Wir sehen das Haus nicht. Ich spiele heute nicht mit dem Hund.

sections.title: --- Something, Nothing, and Everything ---
sections.content: Talk about unspecified things using etwas, nichts, and alles.

sections.title: Etwas (Something / Some)
sections.content: 'Etwas' means something or a little bit of something. It is often shortened to 'was' in spoken German. For example: Ich brauche etwas Wasser. Wir essen etwas.

sections.title: Nichts (Nothing)
sections.content: 'Nichts' means nothing. It acts as a complete negation for an object. For example: Das Kind isst nichts. Ich sehe nichts.

sections.title: Alles (Everything)
sections.content: 'Alles' means everything or all. For example: Die Frau kauft alles. Alles ist gut.

topics.title: Coordinating Conjunctions
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Basic Conjunctions (und, aber, oder, denn), Coordinating Conjunctions

sections.title: --- Basic Conjunctions (und, aber, oder, denn) ---
sections.content: Connect words and simple sentences using common conjunctions without changing word order.

sections.title: und and oder
sections.content: Und means 'and' and oder means 'or' to connect words or sentences. Example: Ich trinke Wasser und Milch. Example: Willst du einen Apfel oder eine Banane? Example: Der Mann liest und das Kind spielt. Example: Die Frau lernt oder sie spielt.

sections.title: aber for contrast
sections.content: Aber means 'but' and shows contrast; verb position stays normal in the second part. Example: Das Auto ist neu, aber das Haus ist alt. Example: Ich bin müde, aber ich lerne Deutsch.

sections.title: denn gives a reason
sections.content: Denn means 'because' and the verb stays in position 2 after denn (unlike weil at higher levels). Example: Ich gehe in die Schule, denn ich lerne Deutsch. Example: Das Kind trinkt Milch, denn es ist durstig.

sections.title: --- Coordinating Conjunctions ---
sections.content: Connect sentences using simple conjunctions like und, aber, and oder.

sections.title: Und and Oder
sections.content: Und means and, while oder means or. These words connect two clauses but do not change the word order. Position 2 still belongs to the verb. For example: Der Mann isst einen Apfel und die Frau trinkt Milch. Gehen wir in die Stadt oder bleiben wir hier?

sections.title: Aber
sections.content: Aber means but. It connects two contrasting ideas without changing the word order of the second clause. For example: Das Haus ist klein, aber der Garten ist groß.

sections.title: Denn
sections.content: Denn means because. It introduces a reason and, unlike other words for because, it does not change the word order of the sentence that follows it. For example: Ich trinke Wasser, denn ich habe Durst.

topics.title: Adjectives & Comparisons
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Adjectives (Basic Use), Using Adjectives, Comparative and Superlative, Intensifiers (sehr vs. zu), Time Expressions: jeden, jede, jedes

sections.title: --- Adjectives (Basic Use) ---
sections.content: Describe people and things with adjectives, and learn a few simple adjective endings with articles.

sections.title: Adjectives with sein (no endings)
sections.content: After sein, adjectives usually have no ending at A1 level focus. Example: Der Hund ist groß. Example: Die Katze ist klein. Example: Das Auto ist neu. Example: Die Stadt ist schön.

sections.title: Adjectives before nouns (simple endings)
sections.content: Before a noun, adjectives often add a small ending; with definite articles in nominative: der große Hund, die kleine Katze, das neue Auto. Example: Der große Hund spielt. Example: Die kleine Katze trinkt Milch.

sections.title: Adjectives with ein-words
sections.content: With ein/mein/dein, you also use simple endings: ein großer Hund, eine kleine Katze, ein neues Auto. Example: Ich habe einen großen Hund. Example: Sie hat ein neues Buch.

sections.title: --- Using Adjectives ---
sections.content: Describe nouns using adjectives with the verb sein.

sections.title: Adjectives after Sein
sections.content: When an adjective comes after the verb sein (to be), it does not get any special endings. It stays in its basic dictionary form. For example: Der Hund ist groß. Das Haus ist klein.

sections.title: Colors
sections.content: Colors work just like other adjectives. Common colors include rot (red), blau (blue), grün (green), gelb (yellow), and schwarz (black). For example: Der Apfel ist rot. Das Wasser ist blau.

sections.title: Opposites
sections.content: Learning adjectives in opposite pairs is very helpful. Examples include gut/schlecht (good/bad), alt/neu (old/new), and schnell/langsam (fast/slow). For example: Das Auto ist schnell. Die Katze ist langsam.

sections.title: --- Comparative and Superlative ---
sections.content: Compare nouns using basic adjective endings like -er and am -sten.

sections.title: The Comparative with -er
sections.content: To compare two things, add '-er' to the end of the adjective and use the word 'als' (than). For example: Der Hund ist schneller als die Katze. Das Haus ist größer als die Stadt.

sections.title: The Superlative with am -sten
sections.content: To say something is 'the most', put 'am' before the adjective and add '-sten' to the end. For example: Der Apfel ist am besten. Das Auto ist am schnellsten.

sections.title: Irregular Comparisons
sections.content: Some common adjectives are irregular and change completely. 'Gut' becomes 'besser' and 'am besten'. 'Gern' becomes 'lieber' and 'am liebsten'. For example: Ich trinke gern Wasser, aber ich trinke lieber Milch. Die Frau isst am liebsten Äpfel.

sections.title: --- Intensifiers (sehr vs. zu) ---
sections.content: Amplify adjectives using sehr (very) and zu (too).

sections.title: Sehr (Very)
sections.content: 'Sehr' means very. It intensifies an adjective in a positive or neutral way. For example: Das Auto ist sehr schnell. Der Apfel ist sehr gut.

sections.title: Zu (Too)
sections.content: 'Zu' means too. It is used when there is an excessive amount of something, usually with a negative meaning. For example: Das Haus ist zu klein. Der Hund ist zu laut.

sections.title: Viel vs. Sehr
sections.content: Use 'sehr' with adjectives. Use 'viel' (a lot / much) with nouns or verbs. For example: Ich trinke viel Wasser. Ich finde das Wasser sehr kalt.

sections.title: --- Time Expressions: jeden, jede, jedes ---
sections.content: Say how often you do things using 'every'.

sections.title: Time Expressions take Accusative
sections.content: In German, when you state a definite time expression without a preposition (like 'every day' or 'next week'), it must be in the accusative case. For example: Ich lerne jeden Tag Deutsch.

sections.title: Masculine, Feminine, Neuter
sections.content: The word for 'every' is 'jeder'. Because time expressions are accusative, masculine nouns use 'jeden'. Feminine nouns use 'jede'. Neuter nouns use 'jedes'. For example: jeden Morgen (every morning), jede Woche (every week), jedes Jahr (every year).

sections.title: Position in the Sentence
sections.content: Like other time expressions, 'jeden Tag' usually goes right after the conjugated verb. For example: Wir trinken jeden Morgen Kaffee. Der Hund spielt jedes Wochenende im Garten.

topics.title: Numbers, Prices & Weights
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Numbers and Prices, Measurements and Quantities

sections.title: --- Numbers and Prices ---
sections.content: Count and ask for prices in German.

sections.title: Numbers 1 to 12
sections.content: The numbers from 1 to 12 are unique and must be memorized: eins, zwei, drei, vier, fünf, sechs, sieben, acht, neun, zehn, elf, zwölf. For example: Ich habe zwei Katzen. Das Kind ist drei Jahre alt.

sections.title: Numbers 13 to 19
sections.content: Numbers from 13 to 19 end in -zehn (ten). For example: dreizehn (13), vierzehn (14). Note the slight changes in sechzehn (16) and siebzehn (17). For example: Die Schule hat fünfzehn Tische.

sections.title: Asking for Prices
sections.content: To ask how much something costs, use the verb kosten. Was kostet... for singular nouns, and Was kosten... for plural nouns. For example: Was kostet der Apfel? Was kosten die Schuhe?

sections.title: --- Measurements and Quantities ---
sections.content: Talk about quantities when shopping or cooking without using plurals.

sections.title: Weights (Gramm and Kilo)
sections.content: When talking about weights like das Gramm and das Kilo, the measurement word stays in the singular form, even if the number is greater than one. For example: Ich kaufe zwei Kilo Äpfel. Wir brauchen hundert Gramm Brot.

sections.title: Volumes (Liter and Glas)
sections.content: The same rule applies to volumes like der Liter and das Glas. For example: Das Kind trinkt drei Glas Milch. Ich brauche zwei Liter Wasser.

sections.title: Feminine Containers (Tasse and Flasche)
sections.content: The exception is for feminine measurement words like die Tasse (cup) and die Flasche (bottle). These do take a plural ending. For example: Wir trinken zwei Tassen Kaffee. Er kauft drei Flaschen Wasser.

exercises.explanation: Auto is singular, so the verb is kostet.

exercises.explanation: The 's' from sechs is dropped before adding -zehn.

exercises.explanation: Measurement words like Kilo do not take a plural ending when used after a number.

exercises.explanation: Feminine containers like Flasche DO take their normal plural ending (-n).

topics.title: Es gibt (There is / There are)
topics.description: Use 'es gibt' to say that something exists, and put the noun in the accusative.

sections.title: Meaning and basic structure
sections.content: Es gibt means 'there is/there are' and is very common for describing places. Example: Es gibt ein Haus. Example: Es gibt eine Schule.

sections.title: Accusative with es gibt
sections.content: The noun after es gibt is accusative, so masculine articles change. Example: Es gibt einen Hund. Example: Es gibt den Tisch. Example: In der Stadt gibt es einen Freund. Example: In der Schule gibt es ein Buch.

sections.title: Using es gibt with places
sections.content: You can add a place with in + dative for location. Example: In der Stadt gibt es Wasser. Example: Im Haus gibt es eine Tür.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Es gibt ___ Hund.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: In der Stadt gibt es ___ Schule.
exercises.explanation: Schule is feminine; in accusative it stays 'eine'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Im Haus gibt es ___ Buch.
exercises.explanation: Buch is neuter; in accusative it stays 'ein'.

topics.title: Common Contractions (im, am, zum, zur)
topics.description: Learn very common short forms like im (in dem), am (an dem), zum (zu dem), and zur (zu der).

sections.title: What a contraction is
sections.content: A contraction is a shorter form of a preposition + article, used all the time in spoken and written German. Example: Ich bin im Haus. Example: Das Buch ist im Haus.

sections.title: im and am
sections.content: Im = in dem (dative), and am = an dem (dative). Example: Der Hund ist im Haus. Example: Die Milch ist im Haus. Example: Der Mann ist am Tisch. Example: Das Kind ist am Tisch.

sections.title: zum and zur
sections.content: Zum = zu dem (dative masculine/neuter), and zur = zu der (dative feminine). Example: Ich gehe zum Freund. Example: Der Mann geht zum Haus. Example: Ich gehe zur Schule. Example: Die Frau geht zur Tür.
