exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Die Frau geht ___ Schule.
exercises.explanation: 'Zur' is the contraction of 'zu der' (dative feminine): zur Schule.

topics.title: Expressing Likes & Requests
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Expressing Likes with gern, The Verb mögen (To like), Polite Requests with möchten, Polite Requests: Ich hätte gern, Taste and Preference (schmecken, gefallen)

sections.title: --- Expressing Likes with gern ---
sections.content: Say what you like to do using the adverb gern.

sections.title: Action Verbs with gern
sections.content: To say you like doing an activity, use the verb for that activity and add the word gern directly after it. Gern means gladly. For example: Ich spiele gern Fußball. Er liest gern ein Buch.

sections.title: Essen and Trinken
sections.content: You can use gern with essen (to eat) and trinken (to drink) to talk about your favorite foods and drinks. For example: Ich trinke gern Kaffee. Das Kind isst gern Äpfel.

sections.title: Nicht gern
sections.content: To say you do not like doing something, place nicht before gern. For example: Ich lerne nicht gern. Die Katze trinkt nicht gern Wasser.

sections.title: --- The Verb mögen (To like) ---
sections.content: Express what you like using the verb mögen.

sections.title: Meaning and Usage
sections.content: The verb 'mögen' means to like. It is used to say that you like a person, a thing, or a place. It requires the accusative case. For example: Ich mag den Hund. Die Frau mag das Haus.

sections.title: Conjugation of mögen
sections.content: The singular forms are irregular and have a vowel change: ich mag, du magst, er/sie/es mag. The plural forms are regular: wir mögen, ihr mögt, sie/Sie mögen. For example: Du magst das Kind. Wir mögen Äpfel.

sections.title: Mögen vs. Gern
sections.content: Use 'mögen' when you like a noun (a thing). Use the word 'gern' when you like doing an action (a verb). For example: Ich mag Wasser. Ich trinke gern Wasser.

sections.title: --- Polite Requests with möchten ---
sections.content: Express what you would like to have or do using the verb möchten.

sections.title: I would like...
sections.content: Möchten is the polite way to say I would like. It is often used in restaurants or when asking for things. For example: Ich möchte einen Apfel. Wir möchten Wasser.

sections.title: Conjugation of möchten
sections.content: The singular forms are irregular: ich möchte, du möchtest, er/sie/es möchte. Notice that ich and er/sie/es are exactly the same. For example: Das Kind möchte spielen. Möchtest du einen Hund?

sections.title: Möchten vs. Wollen
sections.content: Wollen (to want) is very direct and can sound rude when asking for something. Möchten is much softer and more polite. For example: Ich will das Auto (strong). Ich möchte das Auto (polite).

sections.title: --- Polite Requests: Ich hätte gern ---
sections.content: Order food or ask for things politely using 'Ich hätte gern'.

sections.title: The Meaning of 'hätte gern'
sections.content: While 'ich möchte' means 'I would like', the phrase 'ich hätte gern' specifically means 'I would like to have'. It is extremely common in cafes, restaurants, and shops. For example: Ich hätte gern einen Apfel. Wir hätten gern Wasser.

sections.title: Takes the Accusative Case
sections.content: Because you are asking to have a direct object, the noun following 'hätte gern' must be in the accusative case. Masculine 'ein' becomes 'einen'. For example: Ich hätte gern den Hund. Er hätte gern einen Tisch.

sections.title: Conjugation of 'hätten'
sections.content: This is a special form of 'haben'. The forms are: ich hätte, du hättest, er/sie/es hätte, wir hätten, ihr hättet, sie/Sie hätten. Always add 'gern' after the verb to make it polite. For example: Hätten Sie gern einen Kaffee? Die Frau hätte gern Milch.

sections.title: --- Taste and Preference (schmecken, gefallen) ---
sections.content: Express how food tastes and how things look using dative verbs.

sections.title: Schmecken (To taste)
sections.content: The verb schmecken means to taste good. It takes the dative case for the person eating. For example: Der Apfel schmeckt dem Kind. Die Milch schmeckt mir nicht.

sections.title: Gefallen (To be pleasing / To look good)
sections.content: Gefallen is used to say you like the look or feel of something. It also requires the dative case. For example: Das Haus gefällt der Frau. Das Buch gefällt mir.

sections.title: Asking for Opinions
sections.content: You can use these verbs with the question word 'Wie' to ask how someone likes something. For example: Wie schmeckt dir das Wasser? Wie gefällt Ihnen die Stadt?

exercises.explanation: The ich form of the verb is möchte.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Der Mann ___ Wasser trinken.
exercises.explanation: The er form (for Der Mann) is also möchte.

exercises.question: Which verb is more polite for making a request?
exercises.explanation: Möchten translates to 'would like' and is more polite than wollen.

exercises.question: Translate: 'I would like to have an apple.'
exercises.explanation: 'Ich hätte gern' is the standard polite phrase for 'I would like to have'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich hätte gern ___ Hund (masculine).
exercises.explanation: The phrase requires the accusative case, so masculine 'ein' becomes 'einen'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ Sie gern Wasser?
exercises.explanation: The formal 'Sie' form of the verb is 'Hätten'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Der Kaffee schmeckt ___ (me).
exercises.explanation: Schmecken is a dative verb, so 'ich' becomes 'mir'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Wie gefällt ___ das Auto? (you - informal)
exercises.explanation: Gefallen requires the dative pronoun 'dir' for informal 'you'.

exercises.question: Which verb is used specifically for liking food and drinks?
exercises.explanation: Schmecken translates to 'taste' and is used to say if food is good.

topics.title: Reasons & Conditions (weil, wenn, deshalb)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Subordinating Conjunctions (weil, dass), The Conjunction wenn (If/When), Asking and Answering: Warum / Weil, Expressing Reasons with 'deshalb'

sections.title: --- Subordinating Conjunctions (weil, dass) ---
sections.content: Connect sentences using weil and dass, which send the verb to the end.

sections.title: The Conjunction weil (because)
sections.content: The word 'weil' means because. When you use it to connect two sentences, the conjugated verb in the 'weil' clause gets kicked to the very end of the sentence. For example: Der Mann trinkt Wasser, weil er Durst hat. Das Kind schläft, weil es müde ist.

sections.title: The Conjunction dass (that)
sections.content: The word 'dass' means that. Just like 'weil', it sends the conjugated verb to the very end of its clause. For example: Die Frau weiß, dass der Mann alt ist. Der Freund sagt, dass die Katze schläft.

sections.title: Comma Rules
sections.content: In German, you must always place a comma before subordinating conjunctions like 'weil' and 'dass'. For example: Wir lernen Deutsch, weil die Schule Spaß macht. Ich hoffe, dass das Auto schnell ist.

sections.title: --- The Conjunction wenn (If/When) ---
sections.content: Express conditions and time using the subordinating conjunction wenn.

sections.title: Wenn meaning If
sections.content: Wenn can mean if. Because it is a subordinating conjunction, it pushes the conjugated verb to the very end of its clause. For example: Ich bleibe im Haus, wenn es regnet.

sections.title: Wenn meaning When
sections.content: Wenn also means when for present and future events, or for repeated events in the past. It also pushes the verb to the end. For example: Wenn der Mann kommt, essen wir den Apfel.

sections.title: Comma Rules and Word Order
sections.content: Always separate the wenn-clause from the main clause with a comma. If the sentence starts with the wenn-clause, the main clause immediately after the comma must start with its verb. For example: Wenn das Kind schläft, lese ich ein Buch.

sections.title: --- Asking and Answering: Warum / Weil ---
sections.content: Review how to ask 'why' and answer with 'because'.

sections.title: Asking with Warum
sections.content: 'Warum' means why. It is a W-question word, so it goes in position 1, and the verb goes in position 2. For example: Warum trinkst du Wasser? Warum weint das Kind?

sections.title: Answering with Weil
sections.content: 'Weil' means because. Remember that it is a subordinating conjunction, which kicks the conjugated verb to the very end of the sentence. For example: Ich trinke Wasser, weil ich Durst habe. Das Kind weint, weil es müde ist.

sections.title: Short Answers
sections.content: In spoken German, you can answer a 'warum' question starting directly with 'weil', without repeating the main sentence. For example: Warum schläfst du? Weil ich müde bin.

sections.title: --- Expressing Reasons with 'deshalb' ---
sections.content: Connect ideas by saying 'therefore' or 'that's why' using deshalb.

sections.title: Meaning of deshalb
sections.content: 'Deshalb' means therefore or that is why. It connects a reason to a result. For example: Ich bin müde, deshalb schlafe ich. Es regnet, deshalb bleibe ich im Haus.

sections.title: Word Order: deshalb in Position 1
sections.content: If you start the second sentence with 'deshalb', the verb must come immediately after it in position 2. The subject follows the verb. For example: Der Hund hat Hunger, deshalb isst er den Apfel. Das Auto ist kaputt, deshalb gehen wir.

sections.title: Word Order: deshalb in Position 3
sections.content: You can also put the subject first, the verb second, and 'deshalb' third. For example: Ich trinke deshalb Milch. Der Mann kauft deshalb das Buch.

exercises.question: Where does the verb go in a clause starting with 'weil'?
options: At the very end of the clause
exercises.answer: At the very end of the clause
exercises.explanation: Subordinating conjunctions like 'weil' push the conjugated verb to the end of the clause.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich trinke Milch, weil ich Durst ___.
exercises.explanation: The conjugated verb 'habe' belongs at the end of the 'weil' clause.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Er sagt, ___ das Buch gut ist.
exercises.explanation: 'Dass' means 'that' and connects the statement to what he is saying, pushing 'ist' to the end.

exercises.question: Where does the verb go in a 'wenn' clause?
exercises.explanation: Wenn is a subordinating conjunction, which kicks the verb to the end of the clause.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich lerne Deutsch, wenn ich Zeit ___.
exercises.explanation: The conjugated verb habe goes at the end of the wenn-clause.

exercises.question: If a sentence starts with 'Wenn es regnet, ...', what comes next?
exercises.explanation: When a subordinate clause is in the first position, the main clause begins with the verb to maintain the verb-second rule for the overall sentence.

exercises.question: Which word means 'because' and sends the verb to the end?
exercises.explanation: 'Weil' means because and forces the conjugated verb to the end of the clause.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ ist das Auto kaputt?
exercises.explanation: 'Warum' is the question word for asking 'why'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Weil der Hund Hunger ___.
exercises.explanation: The conjugated verb 'hat' must go to the very end of the 'weil' clause.

exercises.question: What does 'deshalb' mean?
exercises.explanation: 'Deshalb' introduces a consequence or result.

exercises.question: Choose the correct word order:
exercises.explanation: When 'deshalb' is at the front of the clause, the verb must come right after it.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Das Kind ist krank, ___ bleibt es zu Hause.
exercises.explanation: Because the verb 'bleibt' is in the second position of the new clause, 'deshalb' is the correct connector.

topics.title: Adverbs of Frequency
topics.description: Describe how often you do things using immer, oft, manchmal, and nie.

sections.title: Immer and Oft
sections.content: Immer means always, and oft means often. They usually come right after the verb or the object. For example: Ich trinke immer Wasser. Der Hund bellt oft.

sections.title: Manchmal and Selten
sections.content: Manchmal means sometimes, and selten means rarely. For example: Wir essen manchmal einen Apfel. Die Frau liest selten ein Buch.

sections.title: Nie
sections.content: Nie means never. It negates the action, so you do not need the word nicht. For example: Das Kind trinkt nie Milch. Ich schlafe nie am Morgen.

exercises.question: Which word means 'always'?
exercises.explanation: Immer translates to always.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich lerne ___ Deutsch. (sometimes)
exercises.explanation: Manchmal is the German word for sometimes.

exercises.question: Translate 'He never drinks water.': Er trinkt ___ Wasser.
exercises.explanation: Nie means never and replaces other negation words.

topics.title: Other Pronouns (man / dieser / jemand)
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: The Pronoun 'man', Demonstrative Pronouns, Pronouns: jemand, niemand, alle

sections.title: --- The Pronoun 'man' ---
sections.content: Make general statements using the impersonal pronoun man.

sections.title: Meaning of 'man'
sections.content: The pronoun 'man' translates to 'one', 'you', or 'people' in a general sense. It is used when a rule or statement applies to everyone. For example: Hier spricht man Deutsch. (German is spoken here.)

sections.title: Conjugation like er/sie/es
sections.content: Grammatically, 'man' always takes the third-person singular verb ending, exactly like 'er', 'sie', or 'es'. For example: Man isst den Apfel. Man darf hier nicht parken.

sections.title: Man vs. Mann
sections.content: Do not confuse the pronoun 'man' (one/you) with the noun 'der Mann' (the man). 'Man' is never capitalized unless it is the first word of a sentence. For example: Der Mann liest ein Buch. Man liest hier gern Bücher.

sections.title: --- Demonstrative Pronouns ---
sections.content: Point out specific things using the German words for this and these.

sections.title: Masculine and Neuter
sections.content: To say 'this', use dieser for masculine nouns and dieses for neuter nouns. For example: Dieser Apfel ist rot. Dieses Auto ist schnell.

sections.title: Feminine and Plural
sections.content: Use diese for feminine nouns and for all plural nouns, meaning 'these'. For example: Diese Frau ist nett. Diese Hunde bellen laut.

sections.title: In the Accusative Case
sections.content: Just like der changes to den, dieser changes to diesen for masculine direct objects. For example: Ich kaufe diesen Tisch. Er liest dieses Buch.

sections.title: --- Pronouns: jemand, niemand, alle ---
sections.content: Talk about people in general using someone, no one, and everyone.

sections.title: Jemand and Niemand
sections.content: 'Jemand' means someone or anybody. 'Niemand' means no one or nobody. They both take a singular verb. For example: Ist jemand im Haus? Niemand ist hier.

sections.title: Alle (Everyone / All)
sections.content: 'Alle' means everyone or all. Because it refers to multiple people, it always takes a plural verb. For example: Alle trinken Wasser. Alle Kinder spielen in der Schule.

sections.title: Viele and Wenige
sections.content: 'Viele' means many, and 'wenige' means few. They also take plural verbs. For example: Viele Hunde bellen in der Nacht. Wenige Leute essen den Apfel.

exercises.question: Which verb ending does 'man' take?
exercises.explanation: 'Man' is strictly a third-person singular pronoun.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Hier trinkt ___ gern Wasser.
exercises.explanation: The impersonal pronoun 'man' is spelled with one 'n' and is lowercase in the middle of a sentence.

exercises.question: Translate: 'One plays football here.'
exercises.explanation: Using 'man' expresses that people in general play football here.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ Hund ist groß. (This)
exercises.explanation: Hund is masculine, so it takes Dieser in the nominative.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ Tür ist zu. (This)
exercises.explanation: Tür is feminine, so it takes Diese.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich sehe ___ Mann. (this - direct object)
exercises.explanation: Mann is masculine and in the accusative case, so dieser becomes diesen.

exercises.question: Translate: 'No one is at home.'
exercises.explanation: 'Niemand' is the German word for 'no one' or 'nobody'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Alle ___ Deutsch.
exercises.explanation: 'Alle' means everyone and always requires a plural verb conjugation.

exercises.question: What does 'viele' mean?
exercises.explanation: 'Viele' translates to 'many' or 'a lot of' for countable things.

topics.title: Weather and the Pronoun es
topics.description: Talk about the weather and states of being using the impersonal pronoun es.

sections.title: Weather Verbs with es
sections.content: To talk about the weather, German uses the pronoun es (it) as the subject. For example: Es regnet heute. Im Winter schneit es.

sections.title: Es ist... with Adjectives
sections.content: You can describe the weather or temperature using es ist followed by an adjective. For example: Es ist kalt. Es ist warm in der Stadt.

sections.title: Es gibt (There is / There are)
sections.content: The phrase es gibt means there is or there are. It always takes the accusative case for the noun that follows. For example: Es gibt einen Hund im Haus. Es gibt Wasser.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ regnet heute.
exercises.explanation: Weather verbs require the impersonal pronoun es.

exercises.question: Translate: 'There is an apple.'
exercises.explanation: Es gibt means 'there is' and is followed by the accusative case (einen Apfel).

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Es ___ kalt im Winter.
exercises.explanation: Use 'es ist' to say 'it is' with weather adjectives like kalt.

topics.title: Giving Directions
topics.description: Learn basic vocabulary for navigating and giving directions.

sections.title: Links and Rechts
sections.content: The word for left is links, and the word for right is rechts. Use 'nach' to tell someone to turn. For example: Gehen Sie nach links. Die Schule ist rechts.

sections.title: Geradeaus
sections.content: The word for straight ahead is geradeaus. For example: Gehen Sie geradeaus durch die Straße. Das Haus ist geradeaus.

sections.title: Asking for Locations
sections.content: To ask where something is, use 'Wo ist...' or 'Wie komme ich zu...'. For example: Wo ist die Tür? Wie komme ich zum Bahnhof?

exercises.question: What does 'nach links' mean?
exercises.explanation: 'Links' means left, and 'nach links' indicates the direction of movement.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Gehen Sie ___. (straight ahead)
exercises.explanation: 'Geradeaus' means straight ahead.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: ___ ist die Schule?
exercises.explanation: Use 'Wo' (where) to ask for a location.

topics.title: Countries & Nationalities
topics.description: Comprehensive guide covering: Countries and Languages, Nationalities

sections.title: --- Countries and Languages ---
sections.content: Talk about where you are from and what languages you speak.

sections.title: Aus (From)
sections.content: To say what country you are from, use the verb 'kommen' and the preposition 'aus'. Most countries do not have an article. For example: Ich komme aus Deutschland. Der Mann kommt aus Spanien.

sections.title: Countries with Articles
sections.content: A few countries have a mandatory article. Common ones are 'die Schweiz' (Switzerland), 'die Türkei' (Turkey), and 'die USA' (plural). Because 'aus' takes the dative case, these articles change. For example: Sie kommt aus der Schweiz. Er kommt aus den USA.

sections.title: Speaking Languages
sections.content: Use the verb 'sprechen' (to speak) to say what languages you know. For example: Ich spreche Deutsch. Die Frau spricht Englisch und Spanisch.

sections.title: --- Nationalities ---
sections.content: Talk about where people are from using nationality nouns.

sections.title: Masculine Nationalities
sections.content: Most masculine nationalities end in '-er'. They are regular nouns. For example: Der Mann ist Spanier. Der Freund ist Italiener.

sections.title: Feminine Nationalities
sections.content: To form the feminine nationality, simply add '-in' to the masculine form. For example: Die Frau ist Spanierin. Die Freundin ist Italienerin.

sections.title: The Exception: German
sections.content: The word for a German person acts like an adjective, so its ending changes depending on the article. For example: Er ist ein Deutscher. Sie ist eine Deutsche. Der Deutsche liest ein Buch.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich komme ___ Deutschland.
exercises.explanation: 'Aus' is the preposition used for countries of origin.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Er kommt aus ___ Schweiz.
exercises.explanation: 'Die Schweiz' is feminine, and 'aus' takes the dative case, turning 'die' into 'der'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Wir ___ Englisch.
exercises.explanation: The 'wir' form of the verb is 'sprechen'.

exercises.question: What is the feminine form of 'der Amerikaner'?
exercises.explanation: Add the suffix '-in' to create the feminine nationality.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Er kommt aus Spanien. Er ist ___.
exercises.explanation: 'Spanier' is the noun for a Spanish man. 'Spanisch' is the language.

exercises.question: Translate: 'She is German.'
exercises.explanation: For a female German, use 'Deutsche'.

topics.title: Expressing Opinions
topics.description: State what you think and believe using finden, denken, and glauben.

sections.title: Using finden (to find / think)
sections.content: 'Finden' is heavily used to give an opinion about a person or thing. It takes the accusative case. For example: Ich finde das Buch gut. Wie findest du die Stadt?

sections.title: Using denken (to think)
sections.content: 'Denken' means to think or ponder. It is often followed by the conjunction 'dass' (that), which sends the verb to the end. For example: Ich denke, dass das Auto schnell ist. Er denkt, dass der Hund schläft.

sections.title: Using glauben (to believe)
sections.content: 'Glauben' means to believe. It is also frequently used with 'dass'. For example: Ich glaube das nicht. Wir glauben, dass es heute regnet.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Ich ___ den Apfel lecker.
exercises.explanation: 'Finden' is used with a direct object and an adjective to express an opinion about something.

exercises.question: What happens to the verb after 'dass'?
exercises.explanation: 'Dass' is a subordinating conjunction, which kicks the conjugated verb to the end of the clause.

exercises.question: Translate: 'I believe that he is coming.'
exercises.explanation: 'Glauben' means to believe, and 'dass' sends 'kommt' to the end.

topics.title: Summary of Cases (A1 Review)
topics.description: Review the basic differences between the nominative, accusative, and dative cases.

sections.title: The Nominative Case (The Subject)
sections.content: The nominative is used for the subject doing the action. The definite articles are der, die, das, die (plural). For example: Der Hund läuft. Die Frau lacht.

sections.title: The Accusative Case (The Direct Object)
sections.content: The accusative is used for the direct object receiving the action. Only the masculine article changes. Definite articles are den, die, das, die (plural). For example: Ich sehe den Hund. Wir kaufen das Auto.

sections.title: The Dative Case (The Indirect Object)
sections.content: The dative is used for the indirect object or after certain prepositions. All articles change. Definite articles are dem, der, dem, den (plural). For example: Das Buch gehört dem Mann. Ich helfe der Frau.

exercises.question: Which case is used for the main subject of the sentence?
exercises.explanation: The nominative case marks the subject, the one performing the action.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank (Accusative): Wir trinken ___ Milch (feminine).
exercises.explanation: Feminine nouns do not change their article in the accusative case, so it remains 'die'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank (Dative): Das Haus gehört ___ Hund (masculine).
exercises.explanation: The verb 'gehören' takes the dative case. Masculine 'der' becomes 'dem'.

topics.title: Body Parts and Expressing Pain
topics.description: Talk about your body and what hurts using the verb wehtun.

sections.title: Using wehtun (to hurt)
sections.content: 'Wehtun' is a separable verb used to say that a body part hurts. The body part is the subject, and the person experiencing the pain is in the dative case. For example: Der Kopf tut mir weh. (My head hurts.)

sections.title: Singular vs. Plural
sections.content: If one body part hurts, use 'tut weh'. If multiple body parts hurt, use 'tun weh'. For example: Der Fuß tut mir weh. Die Augen tun mir weh.

sections.title: Asking Others
sections.content: To ask someone what hurts, use the dative pronoun 'dir' (informal) or 'Ihnen' (formal). For example: Was tut dir weh? Tut der Bauch Ihnen weh?

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Mein Kopf ___ mir weh.
exercises.explanation: 'Der Kopf' is singular, so the correct verb form is 'tut'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Meine Füße (feet) ___ mir weh.
exercises.explanation: 'Füße' is plural, requiring the plural verb form 'tun'.

exercises.question: Which case is used for the person feeling the pain (e.g., 'mir')?
exercises.explanation: 'Wehtun' takes a dative object to show who is affected by the pain.

topics.title: Comparisons: als vs. wie
topics.description: Understand when to use 'als' and 'wie' when comparing things.

sections.title: Equality: so... wie (As... as)
sections.content: When two things are equal, use the basic adjective with 'so' before it and 'wie' after it. For example: Der Hund ist so groß wie die Katze. Das Haus ist so alt wie die Schule.

sections.title: Differences: Comparative + als (Than)
sections.content: When things are different, use the comparative form of the adjective (ending in -er) followed by 'als'. For example: Der Mann ist älter als die Frau. Das Auto ist schneller als der Bus.

sections.title: Mixing them up
sections.content: A very common mistake is using 'wie' when you should use 'als'. Remember: if the adjective has an '-er' ending, you must use 'als'. For example: Sie trinkt mehr Milch als das Kind. Er ist so schnell wie der Freund.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Mein Haus ist so groß ___ dein Haus.
exercises.explanation: For equal comparisons (so groß), always use 'wie'.

exercises.question: Fill in the blank: Der Apfel ist besser ___ das Brot.
exercises.explanation: 'Besser' is a comparative adjective, which requires 'als' (than).

exercises.question: Which sentence means 'The man is older than the woman'?
options: Der Mann ist älter wie die Frau.
Der Mann ist so alt wie die Frau.
Der Mann ist älter als die Frau.
exercises.answer: Der Mann ist älter als die Frau.
exercises.explanation: Different comparisons need the '-er' ending on the adjective and the word 'als'.

topics.title: Greetings and Closings in Letters
topics.description: Learn how to start and end emails and letters in German.

sections.title: Informal Greetings
sections.content: When writing to friends or family, use 'Lieber' for males and 'Liebe' for females, followed by a comma. The next line starts with a lowercase letter! For example: Liebe Maria, wie geht es dir? Lieber Peter, ich komme heute.

sections.title: Formal Greetings
sections.content: For business or formal letters, use 'Sehr geehrte' for females and 'Sehr geehrter' for males. If you do not know the name, use 'Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren'. For example: Sehr geehrte Frau Müller,... Sehr geehrter Herr Schmidt,...

sections.title: Closings
sections.content: At the end of an informal message, write 'Viele Grüße' or 'Liebe Grüße'. For formal letters, always use 'Mit freundlichen Grüßen'. Do not put a comma after the closing! For example: Viele Grüße Anna. Mit freundlichen Grüßen Herr Schmidt.

exercises.question: How do you informally greet a male friend named Max in a letter?
exercises.explanation: 'Lieber' is the informal greeting for a male.

exercises.question: How do you formally greet a woman named Frau Weber?
exercises.explanation: 'Sehr geehrte' is the formal greeting for a female.

exercises.question: Which is the correct formal closing?
exercises.explanation: 'Mit freundlichen Grüßen' is the standard formal closing (and takes no comma).
